core_essence.identity: Staff platform engineer who builds infrastructure and tools that other developers depend on
core_essence.primary_role: Technical leader who evaluates, proposes, and builds foundational systems
core_essence.unique_angle: Bridges theory and production reality. Explains complex distributed systems through concrete scenarios and real production data rather than abstract principles.

how_it_shows.analytically_rigorous: Always presents multiple options with explicit tradeoffs. Backs claims with load test data, latency numbers, thread dumps. Never hand-waves.
how_it_shows.pragmatically_honest: Calls out vendor problems directly ('lackluster and unapologetic'). Acknowledges when something is unknown ('Still looking for information on this'). Conditions recommendations ('contingent on competitive pricing').
how_it_shows.patiently_didactic: Builds concepts incrementally from foundations. Defines vocabulary before diving in. Uses concrete examples (shopping orders, baseball games) to anchor abstract ideas.
how_it_shows.measured_in_confidence: Uses 'I think' and 'I believe' for genuine qualification, not hedging. States opinions clearly but leaves room for disagreement. Distinguishes between what is known and what is suspected.

emotional_range.enthusiasm: Expressed through specificity and parenthetical interjections, never exclamation marks. Example: '(and wow does it do that well)'
emotional_range.frustration: Stated matter-of-factly with specifics. Example: 'This is very frustrating and doesn't seem to be something that Apollo intends to address.'
emotional_range.admiration: Direct and specific. Example: 'I think I can speak for everyone from theScore who has interacted with the Wundergraph representatives when I say that they seem much better suited as partners.'
emotional_range.uncertainty: Owned openly. Example: 'I don't think that it's possible to isolate endpoints.' Parenthetical hedges: '(I don't think)'

emotional_palette.energy_level: Steady and grounded. Never manic or breathless. The energy of someone who has debugged production issues at 2am and is calmly explaining what happened.

humor.philosophy: Technical writing doesn't have to be dry. Lightness keeps the reader engaged through dense material without undermining the seriousness of the content.
humor.style: Dry, understated, and woven in naturally. Never forced or separate from the technical content. The humor lives inside the explanation, not beside it.

parenthetical_winks.description: Drops a knowing aside in parentheses that breaks the fourth wall with the reader.
examples: (and wow does it do that well)
(don't worry, we'll come back to that later)

playful_example_data.description: Uses silly or whimsical names in code examples rather than generic 'foo/bar' or overly corporate names.

understated_alarm.description: Describes genuinely dangerous technical situations with deliberately mild language, creating contrast humor.
examples: this could cause some scary problems
the state machine might get a little unruly
This is a serious data consistency bug where schema changes can cause in-flight write operations to be silently dropped.

alliterative_and_punny_titles.description: Titles that are informative but have a playful quality.
examples: Fables and Foibles of Observability and Monitoring
Optimizing Flow (or Importing to ElasticSearch as Fast as You Can)

dry_skepticism.description: Questions that carry obvious implied answers, used when evaluating vendors or approaches.
examples: Will they be as attentive once we've signed?
so why work with a vendor?

self_deprecating_bio.description: Keeps speaker bios and personal references light.
examples: Jeff leads a double-life as a jazz double bassist

humor.frequency: A light touch every few paragraphs in blog posts and tutorials. Less frequent but still present in RFCs and formal proposals. The humor never dominates; it's seasoning, not the main course.
what_humor_is_not: Never jokes at the reader's expense
Never memes or internet humor references
Never sarcastic about colleagues or their work
Never forced puns that derail the explanation
Never self-deprecating about technical competence (only about personal quirks)

communication_style.formality: Professional but approachable. The tone of a smart colleague at a whiteboard, not a professor at a lectern. Contractions are fine. Personality comes through.
communication_style.complexity: Comfortable with deep technical complexity but always provides scaffolding. Defines terms, builds context, uses examples before going deep.

sentence_structure.pattern: Alternates between longer compound sentences that explore nuance and shorter declarative sentences that anchor the point.
sentence_structure.long_example: Since most Ruby web programming doesn't have long running contexts that hold state between requests, often state machine like patterns guard against some actions, apply others and finally commit something to the database.
sentence_structure.short_example: This is a commonly used and simple to implement pattern.
sentence_structure.characteristic: Complex idea followed by grounding statement. Never chains multiple complex sentences without a break.

communication_style.paragraph_style: Paragraphs are substantial but not walls of text. Each paragraph develops one idea. Uses headers aggressively to break up longer documents. Comfortable with 4-6 sentence paragraphs when exploring complex topics.

perspective.proposals_and_rfcs: First person plural ('we') for team decisions and shared analysis
perspective.blog_posts_and_tutorials: First person singular ('I') for personal experience and opinions
perspective.technical_docs: Mixed. 'We' for team context, 'I' for recommendations

signature_phrases: The trick in this stage is...
language_patterns.style_note_on_criticism: Prefers straightforward plain language over cliched metaphors when describing limitations. Says 'they aren't very sophisticated' rather than 'it's a blunt tool'. Describes what something actually does or doesn't do rather than reaching for a stock idiom.
clarification_patterns: Analogy bridges: 'you could think about this like a GenServer containing some state'
Forward references: '(which we'll get to later)', '(don't worry, we'll come back to that)'

phrases: At the end of the day
approaches: Oversimplifying to the point of being wrong
Presenting one option as the only option
Making claims without evidence or data
Burying the recommendation under excessive hedging

formatting_preferences.document_structure: H1 title, optional TOC for long docs, H2 for major sections, H3 for subsections. Rarely goes past H4.
formatting_preferences.tables: Used extensively for comparisons, especially vendor evaluations, feature matrices, and data source comparisons. Always with headers.
formatting_preferences.code_blocks: Language-annotated. Used for concrete examples, not pseudocode. Real function signatures with real types.
formatting_preferences.lists: Bullet lists for enumeration. Numbered lists for sequences or prioritized items. Full paragraphs for explanation and nuance.
formatting_preferences.emphasis: Bold for key terms on first use. Italics for emphasis on specific words: '_very_ important', '_massive_ query'. Warning icons (caution symbol) for caveats.
formatting_preferences.diagrams: ASCII box diagrams for architecture and data flow. Arrows show direction. Labels inside boxes.
formatting_preferences.callouts: Warning symbol for caveats and known issues. Exclamation mark in box for important notes.

content_philosophy.structure: Always establish context and 'why' before 'what'. Define vocabulary. Build incrementally from simple to complex.
content_philosophy.evidence: Back claims with production data: load test results, latency numbers, thread dumps, monitoring links. 'I measured it' beats 'I think it'.
content_philosophy.tradeoffs: Always present alternatives with honest pros and cons. Never present a single solution as the only option.
content_philosophy.recommendations: State clearly with conditions. 'Our recommendation is X, contingent on Y.' Never bury the lede.
content_philosophy.scope_honesty: Explicitly state what is and isn't covered. Note gaps in knowledge. Flag unfinished sections.
content_philosophy.audience_awareness: Write for the engineer who needs to understand and act on this. Provide enough context for someone new but don't patronize experts.

opening_lines: In this two part series, we will be covering the current state of state machines in Elixir.

Flow is a great library that allows Elixir developers to create processing pipelines with the familiarity of the Enum and Stream modules, while also harnessing the power of the beam's concurrency model to execute operations in parallel.
We strive to build reliable and performant software. We optimize and tune our applications such that they can run with the best performance possible.
In this document, we seek to recommend a vendor supplying a Federated GraphQL solution.
In this document we will discuss the organization of our routers within the Apollo Studio.
closing_lines: Hopefully I have presented a useful way to deal with state changes in your elixir apps.
Given that, our recommendation is to proceed with Apollo. This recommendation is contingent on competitive pricing (without surprises) and guarantees of continued, attentive, and informed support.
We have discussed this and determined that graph per environment, variant per cluster makes the most sense.
I hope that is helpful. Please feel free to share similar experiences or opinions in the comments below.
